, the third largest in the country. It is the capital city of the
province and the headquarters of the Kisumu district. It lies on a bay on the Eastern shore of Lake Victoria.
The city was founded by the British under the name Port Florence in 1901. It was originally a stop on the railway between

. A year later, the city was renamed Kisumu, from a Luo word meaning “market, trading place”.

In 2006, Kisumu was designated one of Africa's 11 'Millenium Cities' by the United Nations Human Settlements Programme (UN-Habitat).

Kisumu enjoys a tropical savanna climate. The lowest temperatures (about 12°C at night and 17°C to 19°C by day) occur in August and September. The highest daytime temperatures can reach 37°C in the warm season (December to April).

The rain season is from March to May. A secondary rain season occurs in November and December. The dryest month is January.
. There are two daily flights to the capital
. The flight lasts about 45 minutes and takes you above lakes Naivasha and Nakuru. The low-cost company
also operates direct flights to Nairobi and
. Other companies offer flights to and from Kisumu, including

.

The airport is about 3.5 km from the city. The road is unpaved. A few taxis and
minibuses do the journey between the airport and the city. In 2009, a matatu cost about 30 to 40 KSH and a taxi cost about 500 to 600 KSH. Some hotels and car rental companies can arrange pickups.
Several ferries used to link Kisumu with other cities on Lake Victoria. Ferry service on Lake Victoria was marred by a series of grave accidents in the 1990s and 2000s
, with several ships sinking, and the service was discontinued. In 2011,
announced a new, safer service, with one ferry (the MV Amani) operating since October 2012 but no service out of Kisumu as of 2013.
, operated by Kenyan Railways connects Kisumu to

, departing on Sunday, Tuesday and Thursday nights. This is a night train in both directions and the trip lasts about 13 hours (or more, delays are frequent). There are first-class compartments with 2 beds, second-class compartments with 4 beds, and third-class carriages with seats. There is a restaurant car where food is cooked on demand from fresh ingredients. The price of a first-class ticket includes dinner and breakfast.
Several companies operate buses between Nairobi and Kisumu. The trip lasts between 6½ and 8 hours depending on the company.

value: : this is the largest company in the country. It is the safest and the most comfortable but not the cheapest, a ticket costs KSH 500. Buses depart from Lagos Road, and the ticket office is on Wabera Street near the city hall.
: cheaper but slower and less comfortable than
. Expect little legroom, broken air conditioning, and a worn out suspension. Buses depart from Uyoma Street, and the ticket office is at the intersection of Muindi Mbingu Street and Monrovia Street.
. Buses depart from Haile Selassie Avenue and the ticket office is also located there.

Each company runs two trips a day, one departing early in the morning, the other late at night. Day buses are safer as the night buses have been known to be attacked by highway robbers.

In Nairobi, the buses depart from the Country Bus Station near Wakulima Market, between Pumwani Road and Landheis Road.

Make sure to have an international driving license. You can obtain one from the Road Transport Office in Nairobi. Traveling by day is recommended as the roads can be unsafe at night. You may encounter police stops.

From Nairobi, the distance is about 380km. Take Chimoro Road towards

, then turn onto A104 (Waiyaki Way) past Naivasha and Nakuru. About 30km past Nakuru, turn left onto B1 towards Kisumu. The trip can take from 5 to 12 hours depending on whether you want to stop and observe Lake Nakuru, Lake Naivasha and
Kisumu is a small town with lots to see,you can use the notorious boda boda (bicycle taxi), pikipiki (motorcycle taxis),
, buses, or you can simply rent a car.

value: content=This is the second largest open air market in Kenya, and one of the oldest. It is located on Jomo Kenyatta Highway, north-east of the city center, about 1.5km from the long distance bus stop. The market is active day and night every day.

Aside from the town centre there are a number of places to eat and drink in the evenings in the Kondele region on both Kibos Road and Jomo Kenyatta Highway with guest houses close by to sleep in too.

value: content=Local and international cuisine. One of the best classical restaurants.
content=Local and international cuisine from fresh produce. Probably the best fast food in the city.
address=Mega Plaza on Oginga Odinga Rd

content=Local and international cuisine. You need a member card from the club (temporary cards are available).

Aside from the town centre there are a number of places to eat and drink in the evenings in the Kondele region on both Kibos Road and Jomo Kenyatta Highway with guest houses close by to sleep in too.

Kisumu has a number of Guest Houses, hotels, motels, hostels, all dependent on your needs and budget. It is common for hotels and bed and breakfast accommodation to be called a Guest House in Kisumu Kenya. They are the most common and best value places to stay — hotels seem to ramp up their prices just because they are a hotel — beware.

value: content=A 5 minute walk from town center. Its prices at $18. House converted to a lovely guest house hotel in Kisumu that offers en-suite facilities with a communal lounge with digital TV and a communal Kitchen, a free to use computer with free access to the Internet. Free daily breakfast too. Small garden front and back with free parking. Secure double gated with guards quiet residential estate.
is in the heart of the city, mountain view resorts at the suburbs.

content=Is situated in the heart of Africa and on the shores of the World's second largest fresh water lake - Lake Victoria. The hotel has a reputation of upholding traditional hospitality values despite the changing times.

content=Is within main town Kisumu and is considered to be easily the best value accommodation at $7 in the city. Mosquito nets are provided and a lovely outdoor but surrounded yard with tables and to sit and chat. They also provide breakfast.
content=Is situated at the Mamboleo suburbs of Kisumu City and offers semi affordable, decent and rather pleasant accommodation. 10 minutes drive from the City center, bus terminus and Airport.
directions=At the intersection of Oginga Odinga Road with Kendu Lane.

content=Very clean, hot showers, mosquito nets and window screens, TV with satellite, a beautiful roof top terrace with lake view. Seems to be the only cheap place in town that has free Wifi, even in the rooms.
directions=Oposite of Lake View Hotel, about 30m from corner with Oginga Odinga Rd.
content=Clean place with a view of the lake from rooms 1 to 7. Good security and you can lock the room with your own padlock. Clean large mosquito nets, ok bathroom with hot shower only in theory.

Kisumu is less stressful than Nairobi or Mombasa. However pickpockets are common, especially around Kibuye Market. If you are driving, you should lock the car doors.

All public buildings (airport, post office, banks, shopping centers, etc.) are watched by security guards wearing a blue uniform. Private estates are generally guarded as well.

value: Phone: (20 is the national prefix for police forces)
There are police stations all over the city and policemen are clearly visible. The headquarters are located on Nairobi Road near the long distance bus terminal.
name=Aguch Kisumo Public Information Resource Center

All cybercafes have phone booths. Beware that the rates to phone abroad are very high in Kenya. It is usually cheaper to buy a Kenyan SIM card in a cybercafe or from a phone vendor.

The main operators are
(also known as Zain Kenya). Safaricom is slightly cheaper but the quality is less good and the network is often overloaded.
